metadata.title: Effects of nano-hydroxyapatite on the formation of biofilms by Streptococcus mutans in two different media

Effects of nano-hydroxyapatite on the formation of biofilms by Streptococcus mutans in two different media
Miseon Park, John B. Sutherland, Fatemeh Rafii⁎
Division of Microbiology, National Center for Toxicological Research, FDA, Jefferson, AR 72079, USA
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Biofilm Streptococcus mutans Nano-hydroxyapatite Polysaccharide Glucosyltransferase
A B S T R A C T
Objectives: The aim of this study was to examine the effect of nano-hydroxyapatite (nHA) on biofilm formation by Streptococcus mutans, which is actively involved in the initiation of dental caries. Design: The effects of nHA on growth and biofilm formation by S. mutans were investigated in two media: a saliva analog medium, basal medium mucin (BMM); and a nutrient-rich medium, brain heart infusion (BHI); in the presence and absence of sucrose. Results: Sucrose enhanced the growth of S. mutans in both media. In the presence of sucrose, nHA enhanced bacterial growth and biofilm formation more in BMM medium than in BHI.
nHA also affected the transcription of glucosyltransferase (gtf) genes and production of polysaccharide differently in the two media. In BHI medium, the transcription of all three gtf genes, coding for enzymes that synthesize soluble and insoluble glucans from sucrose, was increased more than 3-fold by nHA. However, in BMM medium, only the transcription of gtfB and gtfC, coding for insoluble glucans, was substantially enhanced by nHA. Conclusions: nHA appeared to enhance biofilm formation by increasing glucosyltransferase transcription, which resulted in an increase in production of insoluble glucans. This effect was influenced by the growth conditions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Dental caries is initiated by formation of a microbial biofilm, which is a cluster of organized bacterial cells, on a tooth surface (Gibbons, 1989). Streptococcus mutans is considered an important bacterium in the initiation of dental caries (Colby & Russell, 1997). As a part of the oral microflora, S. mutans is exposed to saliva and nutrient-rich foods and produces acids and polysaccharides from dietary carbohydrates (Colby & Russell, 1997; Walker, Brown, & Taylor, 1984). The extracellular polysaccharides (glucans) that it produces for adherence to the tooth surface may facilitate the adherence of other pathogenic bacteria (Bowen & Koo, 2011; Krzysciak, Jurczak, Koscielniak, Bystrowska, & Skalniak, 2014). They provide a suitable microenvironment in the plaque biofilm as well as a mechanically stable shelter for bacteria that is hard to remove (Bowen & Koo, 2011). Organic acids produced by bacterial metabolic activities in the plaque biofilm may dissolve hydroxyapatite, a major constituent of tooth enamel (Hannig & Hannig, 2010; Pepla, Besharat, Palaia, Tenore, & Migliau, 2014). This may result in enamel demineralization and initiate the development of dental caries (Gao et al., 2016). The plaque biofilm also reduces bacterial exposure to therapeutic agents (Zhang et al., 2015).
In S. mutans, glucans are synthesized from sucrose by three different glucosyltransferases (GtfB, GtfC and GtfD) (Bowen & Koo, 2011; Hamada & Torii, 1980; Mattos-Graner et al., 2004; Ooshima et al., 2001; Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998). The Gtf enzymes of S. mutans are virulence factors that, in addition to utilizing carbohydrates to generate acidic conditions causing tooth demineralization, also produce the polysaccharides required for the formation of biofilms (Loesche, 1986; Yamashita, Bowen, Burne, & Kuramitsu, 1993; Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998). Because of the role of Gtf enzymes in biofilm formation, various compounds have been examined for their influence on the transcription of gtf genes (Jeon et al., 2009; Vahid-Dastjerdi et al., 2016; Wunder & Bowen, 1999; Yabuta et al., 2018; Yoo & Jwa, 2018) to find out if they can be used as an alternative approach for the prevention of cariogenic biofilms (Ren, Chen et al., 2016; Ren, Cui et al., 2016).
The gtfB, gtfC and gtfD genes code for production of the proteins GtfB, GtfC and GtfD, respectively. GtfB synthesizes an insoluble glucan with α-(1–3)-glycosidic linkages, which binds to the bacterial surface and also has other glucan-binding domains (Mooser & Wong, 1988; Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998). GtfD produces a water-soluble glucan with α-(1–6)-glycosidic linkages (Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998). GtfC produces both soluble and insoluble glucans and also absorbs to

hydroxyapatite in the enamel (Bowen & Koo, 2011; Mooser & Wong, 1988; Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998). The insoluble glucan adheres to other bacteria and solid surfaces via GtfB and GtfC (Bowen & Koo, 2011; Mooser & Wong, 1988; Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998). This results in clustering and cohesion of bacteria to form plaque biofilm. Stable biofilm is formed when the ratio of GtfB:GtfC: GtfD is 20:1:4 (Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998; Ooshima et al., 2001). By concentrating protons on the cell surface of S. mutans, glucans may also allow the cells to adapt to acid stress (Guo, McLean, Lux, He, & Shi, 2015).
Because demineralization of hydroxyapatite in enamel by acids, including those produced by bacteria in the plaque, is important in the development of dental caries, nano-hydroxyapatite (nHA) has been used in toothpaste for remineralization of enamel (Huang, Gao, Cheng, & Yu, 2011; Pepla et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2015). In addition to enamel demineralization by bacteria, host factors, including saliva, and diet influence the development of dental caries (Faustova et al., 2018; Gupta et al., 2013). In the current study, we have examined the effect of nHA on the growth and biofilm formation of S. mutans in two different media that simulated saliva and a nutrient-rich environment.

sections.heading: 2.1. Media and reagents
sections.text: Nano-hydroxyapatite particles, 20–50 nm in size, were obtained from Alfa Aesar as a solution of 5–10% (w/v) in water. MTT (3-[4,5- dimethyl(thiazol)-2-yl]-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide) was obtained from EMD Millipore Corp. The stock solution for staining live cells was prepared by dissolving 0.5 g/ml of MTT in PBS (pH 7.4). Bromocresol green was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Basal medium mucin (BMM), a saliva analog, was prepared according to the published instructions (Wong & Sissons, 2001). Brain heart infusion (BHI) powder was obtained from Oxoid and the liquid medium was prepared according to the supplier’s instructions.

sections.heading: 2.2. Bacterial culture
sections.text: S. mutans ATCC 25175 was obtained from ATCC. A single colony of S. mutans was grown anaerobically in BHI overnight at 37 °C for use in experiments.

sections.heading: 2.3. Effect of nHA on the growth of S. mutans in the presence and absence of sucrose
sections.text:
10 μl of an overnight culture of S. mutans grown in BHI at 37 °C was added to 10ml of BMM or BHI (˜106/ml) and used immediately as inoculum in a 48-well microtiter plate (Fisher Scientific). Triplicate wells contained BMM or BHI with equal amounts of inoculum with 0, 1, or 5% nHA (0.5 and 2.5 mg/ml) and 0 or 1% sucrose in a total volume of 500 μl. Sterile control wells with the same components were not inoculated.
For measuring the kinetics of growth, the plates were first incubated for 3 h in the anaerobic chamber (85% N2, 10% CO2 and 5% H2) at 37 °C. Next, the wells were overlaid by 5 drops of heavy mineral oil (Macron Fine Chemicals) and the plates were transferred to a Synergy Mx spectrophotometer (BioTek) for further incubation. The kinetics program of the BioTek spectrophotometer (Gen 5) was programmed to measure the optical density of the samples at 600 nm every 30min at 37 °C for 24 h. The effect of nHA on the growth of S. mutans was measured by monitoring the absorbance during growth with 0, 1 or 5% nHA in the presence and absence of 1% sucrose.
In duplicate experiments, 48-well plates were incubated at 37 °C in an anaerobic chamber incubator. For detecting the effect of nHA on the pH of the cultures, a solution of bromocresol green (BCG, 1mg/ml) was added to the wells. Reduction of BCG was quantified by measuring the absorbance at 620 and 440 nm during incubation in the
spectrophotometer. pH paper was also used to measure the pH in the wells after 24 h incubation.

sections.heading: 2.4. Effect of nHA on cell survival measured by colony forming units (CFU)
sections.text:
The contents of the wells of microtiter plates with S. mutans grown with 0 and 5% nHA, in the presence and absence of 1% sucrose, were used after incubation for total cell counting. The cells that had formed biofilms at the bottoms of the wells were dislodged using a cell scraper. All planktonic and biofilm cells were removed by pipetting. The cultures were sonicated in a FS3 Sonicator (Fisher Scientific) at 40 kHz for 5min and then vortexed at maximum speed for 20 s (Cheng et al., 2013). BHI agar plates were inoculated with bacterial cultures, using a Spiral Plater WASP2 (Microbiology International) and incubated at 37 °C inside the anaerobic glove box for the growth of bacterial colonies. The CFUs were either counted directly or calculated using a Protocol 3 colony counter from Microbiology International.
2.5. Detection of the effect of nHA on biofilm formation by MTT staining
The effect of nHA on biofilm formation by S. mutans was assayed by measuring the formazan produced from the reduction of MTT by live cells in the biofilm (Liu et al., 2017). Cultures of S. mutans, prepared in 48-well microtiter plates in the presence and absence of 1% sucrose and 5% nHA and grown for 24 h, were used. As controls, duplicate wells without bacteria were included. During growth, the GTF enzymes produce polysaccharides from sucrose and mediate the attachment of polysaccharides and nHA (if present) to the surface of S. mutans, resulting in cell clustering and formation of biofilms in the wells. For colorimetric measurements of the cells in the biofilm that were formed in each well, the contents of the wells were removed. Next, 1 ml of PBS (pH 7.4) was added to each of the wells. The plates were agitated with gentle shaking, after which the buffer was removed and the plates were inverted to drain all of the liquid. Next, 0.5 ml of MTT solution (0.5 mg/ ml of MTT in PBS buffer, pH 7.4) was added to each of the wells. The plates were incubated in the dark at 37 °C for 0.5 h. During incubation, the soluble yellow MTT was reduced by the live cells in the biofilm to the insoluble purple formazan.
After the formazan had been produced, the MTT staining solution from each of the wells was totally removed and replaced with 400 μl of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The plates were incubated again at 37 °C to allow the solubilization and extraction of formazan. The DMSO, containing formazan, was removed from the wells and the absorbance of formazan was measured at 570 nm by a Synergy Mx spectrophotometer (Li et al., 2018). The amounts of formazan produced in different wells of plates containing S. mutans, treated and untreated with sucrose and nHA, were reflective of the numbers of live cells present in the biofilms.

sections.heading: 2.6. RNA extraction and real-time PCR (qRT-PCR)
sections.text:
The effects of nHA and sucrose on the transcription of glucosyltransferase genes in S. mutans were measured by comparing the gene expression in bacteria grown with and without nHA in the presence and absence of 1% sucrose. S. mutans cells grown in BMM and BHI, with and without 5% nHA (in BMM) or 3% nHA (in BHI) and sucrose, were used for RNA extraction.
Because of the high viscosity of cultures of S. mutans in BHI medium containing 5% nHA and 1% sucrose, the efficiency of RNA extraction was very low. To improve the yield of RNA, 3% rather than 5% nHA was used for extraction of RNA from BHI cultures. The bacteria were harvested at the mid to late logarithmic phase (4–7 h) and centrifuged at 5000 x g. The pellets were suspended in an RNA protection reagent (QIAGEN) and incubated for 15min at room temperature. 15mg/ml of lysozyme and 1.7mg/ml of proteinase K were added to the pellets, which were then incubated for 1 h at 40 °C. The samples were mixed with MicroBeads (MoBio) and homogenized for 5min in a Bullet
Blender homogenizer (Next Advance). The RNA was extracted using an RNeasy kit and RNAse (QIAGEN) according to the supplier’s instructions. Primers used for qRT-PCR (Table 1) were either those published for gtf genes (Stipp, Goncalves, Hofling, Smith, & Mattos-Graner, 2008) or designed using DNA STAR software. The RNA extracted from S. mutans cultures, grown in BMM and BHI with and without nHA and sucrose, was used to synthesize cDNA by using Superscript™ III FirstStrand Synthesis SuperMix (Invitrogen). SYBR® GreenER™ qPCR SuperMix (Invitrogen) was used to perform qRT-PCR for comparing the effects of sucrose and nHA on gene transcription. 1 ng of the cDNA template was used in 10 μl of reaction mix containing SYBR® GreenER™ qPCR SuperMix and 2 μM of each forward and reverse primer (Ponchel et al., 2003).
A CFX96 real-time thermocycler (Bio-Rad) was programmed as follows: 50 °C for 2min, 95 °C for 8.5min, to inactivate uracil DNA glycosylase and activate DNA polymerase, and then 40 cycles of 95 °C for 15 s and 60 °C for 30 s, for amplification of cDNA. Melting curves were monitored at 65–90 °C (0.5 °C increase per 5 s) to detect nonspecific gene amplification. For normalization of cycle threshold, 1 ng of cDNA of a 16 S rRNA gene of equivalent size was amplified (Park & Rafii, 2018). As controls for excluding genomic DNA contamination, reaction mixtures were prepared without reverse transcriptase. Reaction mixtures without templates or cDNA were also included as controls to insure lack of contamination by chromosomal DNA. Triplicate assays were performed on RNA extracted from each of three different cultures. The relative levels of expression of each of the genes with respect to 16 S rRNA were determined using the cycle threshold 2−ΔCT method (Ponchel et al., 2003). The relative levels of expression of RNA for each gtf gene, from samples treated with nHA, sucrose or both, were compared to RNA from samples grown with media without either one, by calculating the fold increase using the 2−ΔΔCT method to determine the effect of nHA and sucrose on transcription (Park & Rafii, 2018) following the Real-Time PCR Application Guide from Bio-Rad.

sections.heading: 2.7. Measurement of polysaccharides
sections.text:
Cultures of S. mutans were grown under anaerobic conditions at 37 °C in 48-well plates in either BMM or BHI medium, with or without 1% sucrose and 5% nHA. After 24 h of incubation, the planktonic cells and the culture media were removed by pipetting and biofilms formed at the bottoms of the plates were washed three times with PBS (pH 7.4).The amounts of polysaccharides associated with biofilms were measured according to a published method (Masuko et al., 2005) with some modifications. Water (200 μl) was added to each well, followed by 150 μl of concentrated H2S04, and mixed well. The plates were incubated at room temperature with gentle shaking until all the samples became homogenized. Next, 120 μl of 5% phenol was added to each of the wells and the plates then were incubated at room temperature for 10min. The absorbances were measured at 490 nm by the BioTek spectrophotometer. Different concentrations of sucrose were used as standards.
2.8. Effect of nHA on formation of biofilm on hydroxyapatite-covered pegs
MBEC plates (Innovotech), in which the lid pegs were coated by hydroxyapatite, were used according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The 96-well MBEC plates, containing media with or without 1% sucrose and 5% nHA or both, were inoculated with S. mutans. The peg lids were inserted into the plates and the plates were incubated under anaerobic conditions for 24 h at 37 °C with gentle shaking. For the detection of biofilms on the pegs, the peg lids were sonicated according to the instructions by Innovotech by insertion of the plates into the water bath sonicator with a stainless-steel insert tray. Bacteria released from the pegs were counted as previously described in section 2.4.

sections.heading: 2.9. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Statistical analysis was performed using Microsoft Excel for Office 365 and version 13 Sigma Plot. Duplicate or triplicate wells were used to assay the effect of nHA on S. mutans grown in different media in the presence or absence of sucrose, and each experiment was repeated at least three times. The data were transferred to an Excel spreadsheet for statistical analysis. Excel was used to plot, analyze and compare the kinetics of growth to find the effect of nHA over time on the logarithmic phase, maximum growth of cells and pH of the cultures in different media. Analyses of the effect of nHA on production of polysaccharide, biofilm formation and expression of gtf genes were also performed with Excel. The variability of data from replicate experiments was determined by measuring the mean and standard deviation using the STDEV function of Excel. The statistical significance of bacterial survival in media treated with 0% and 5% nHA, with and without sucrose, were evaluated using a SigmaPlot One Way Analysis of Variance followed by a post-hoc Tukey’s test (p < 0.05%). The p values for polysaccharide and biofilm formation were detected by Student’s t-test using Excel.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of nHA on growth of S. mutans in different media
sections.text:
The kinetics of the growth of S. mutans in BMM and BHI media, with or without nHA and sucrose, is shown in Fig. 1. The highest increases in A600 in both BMM (Fig. 1A) and BHI (Fig. 1B) were detected in cultures grown with 5% nHA and 1% sucrose, in which the optical density increased during the first 12 h of incubation. It then remained at a steady state in BMM medium (Fig. 1A) but continued to increase in BHI medium (Fig. 1B). In the presence of 1% sucrose, 1% nHA enhanced the culture optical density to a lesser extent (Supplementary Fig. 1).
The effect of nHA on cell survival was also measured by determining the CFU of cultures grown with and without nHA after 24 h incubation (Table 2). There were more viable cells in cultures containing both 5% nHA and 1% sucrose than in cultures with either sucrose or nHA alone (Table 2). This effect was more pronounced in BMM medium than in BHI medium. BHI medium, which contains glucose, supported the growth of S. mutans better than BMM medium (Table 2). The addition of 5% nHA or 1% sucrose did not affect bacterial survival in BHI medium, but when both sucrose and nHA were added, survival increased in both BMM and BHI cultures (Table 2).
In BMM cultures containing 1% sucrose alone, there was a reduction of CFU, which could have resulted from a decrease in pH of cultures due to metabolism of sucrose. This was shown by monitoring the absorbance of bromocresol green (Supplementary Fig. 2) and measuring the culture pH. The pH of overnight cultures of S. mutans grown in BMM medium containing 1% sucrose was 4.5, in contrast to pH 4.8 in BMM cultures containing 1% sucrose and 5% nHA. Cell free supernatants of S. mutans grown with sucrose and 5% nHA supported the growth of S. mutans better than supernatants of S. mutans grown in sucrose alone (Supplementary Fig. 3). The increase of CFU in the presence of sucrose
and nHA corresponded to increases in rate of growth and turbidity of cultures grown with both sucrose and nHA (Fig. 1).
3.2. Effect of nHA on biofilm formation
The effect of nHA on the formation of biofilms by S. mutans grown with and without sucrose was shown by MTT staining (Fig. 2 and Supplementary Fig. 4). More formazan was released from biofilms in the cultures grown with 1% sucrose and 5% nHA than in the other cultures (Fig. 2). nHA enhanced biofilm formation in BMM medium more than in BHI. Increased biofilm formation was also visualized in the microtiter plates by the higher intensity of the purple color of formazan in the wells before destaining (Supplementary Fig. 4). The purple color indicated the viable cells in the biofilm, since planktonic cells had been removed. Duplicate wells without bacteria did not
produce detectable amounts of formazan.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of 5% nHA on the production of polysaccharides
sections.text: The amounts of insoluble polysaccharides, presumably glucans, formed in the cultures of S. mutans grown in BMM and BHI media in the presence and absence of 1% sucrose and 5% nHA or both, were measured (Fig. 3). Higher amounts of polysaccharides were produced in cultures containing sucrose. Addition of 5% nHA resulted in an increase in production of polysaccharide that was greater in BMM than in BHI (Fig. 3).

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of nHA on the expression of glucosyltransferase genes
sections.text:
The effect of nHA on the transcription of gtf genes was determined by qRT-PCR. Fig. 4 shows the fold increase in the expression of gtf genes in cultures grown with sucrose, nHA or both compared to their transcription in cultures grown in BMM or BHI alone. More than 1.5-fold increases in gtfB, gtfC and gtfD transcription were observed in some of the cultures grown under different conditions. When S. mutans was grown in BMM medium with sucrose and nHA, the highest fold increase (6.0-fold) in transcription was observed for the gtfC gene, which codes for an enzyme producing both soluble and insoluble polysaccharides, but only a 1.6-fold increase in the transcription of gtfD, which codes for an enzyme producing soluble polysaccharides. When S. mutans was grown in BHI medium with sucrose and nHA, the highest fold increase in transcription was observed for gtfD (4.6-fold increase), followed by gtfC (4.2- fold increase). The fold increase in transcription in gtfB, which codes for an enzyme producing insoluble glucan, was also higher in S. mutans grown in BMM (4.2-fold) than that grown in BHI (3.2-fold).
3.5. Effect of nHA on biofilm formation on hydroxyapatite-covered pegs
The increase in biofilm formation by S. mutans was observed in 48- well plates and was attributed to the presence of nHA rather than

hydroxyapatite. In an experiment using an MBEC plate in which lid pegs covered by hydroxyapatite were inserted into BMM medium, with or without sucrose and nHA or both, a higher increase in biofilm formation (p < 0.01) was observed by cell counting on pegs incubated in 1% sucrose with 5% nHA than on those incubated in 1% sucrose alone. Higher amounts of biofilm were also formed at the bottoms of the wells containing 5% nHA and 1% sucrose than in other wells (Supplementary
Fig. 5).

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
The activities of S. mutans glucosyltransferases result in the production of polysaccharides important for biofilm formation and generation of acidic conditions for the initiation of dental caries (Loesche, 1986; Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998; Yamashita, Bowen, Burne, & Kuramitsu, 1993). In this study, it was shown that nHA enhanced the transcription of all of the gtf genes. This resulted in an increase in polysaccharides and formation of biofilms in the presence of sucrose, especially in BMM medium. Previously it has been shown that sucrose upregulates the transcription of gtf genes in S. mutans (Hudson & Curtiss, 1990). Our study showed that nHA enhanced the transcription of gtfB, gtfC and gtfD differently in S. mutans grown in BMM and BHI media with sucrose. In BMM medium, the presence of nHA resulted in the enhanced transcription of gtfB and gtfC, which encode enzymes mainly producing insoluble glucans, more than that of gtfD, which encodes an enzyme producing soluble glucans (Bowman & Koo, 2013). In BHI medium, nHA produced a higher increase in the transcription of gtfD. This is consistent with previous reports (Walker et al., 1984;
Wiater, Pleszczynska, Prochniak, & Szczodrak, 2012) that variation in growth conditions affects the number and proportion of glucans with α(1–3) and α-(1–6) glycosidic linkages produced by S. mutans, which reflects the relative activities of the glucosyltransferases. The optimum ratio of the three different glucosyltransferases produced by S. mutans is important for stable biofilm formation (Ooshima et al., 2001; VaccaSmith & Bowen, 1998). Deletion of gtfB and gtfC reduces extracellular matrix production and biofilm formation (Yamashita et al., 1993). The different effects of nHA on the transcription of gtf genes in BMM and BHI were reflected in the production of insoluble polysaccharides. The insoluble polysaccharide produced in the bottom of the wells in BMM medium containing both nHA and sucrose was 60% more than the amount produced with sucrose alone. In BHI medium, this difference was only 28%. This is consistent with previous findings that increases in the transcription of gtfB and gtfC produce more insoluble glucan (Bowen & Koo, 2011).
Increases in insoluble polysaccharide synthesis in cultures containing nHA and sucrose were correlated with a rapid increase in culture turbidity during kinetic analysis. GtfB binds to bacterial surfaces, GtfC has high affinity for hydroxyapatite, and GtfD has low affinity for hydroxyapatite (Vacca-Smith & Bowen, 1998). In the cultures containing nHA and sucrose, increased binding of glucosyltransferase to polysaccharides, nHA and bacterial surfaces resulted in increased biofilm biomass, due to the assembly of a polysaccharide-rich matrix and the development of 3D architecture (Xiao et al., 2012). The amount of biofilm formed by S. mutans in BMMmedium with nHA and sucrose was 42% higher than that formed in the same medium with 1% sucrose alone, but in BHI medium it was only 9.5% higher.
Our finding of enhanced transcription of gtfD and a lower increase in biofilm formation in BHI medium is consistent with the finding (Freedman, Birked, & Granath, 1978) that glucan synthesis-defective mutants that had diminished virulence synthesized more of the highly branched α-(1–6)-rich extracellular glucan than the wild type. The higher amount of biofilm formed in BMM indicates higher transcription of gtfB and gtfC. Water-insoluble polysaccharides with α-(1–3) glycosidic linkages, produced by GtfB and GtfC enzymes, provide the matrix necessary for biofilm integrity and for bacterial growth and survival (Li & Burne, 2001).
The increase in biofilm formation on the hydroxyapatite-covered pegs of MBEC plates incubated in BMM medium with nHA and sucrose, in comparison with pegs exposed to sucrose alone, indicated that nHA was a stimulatory factor for the higher number of surviving cells bound to hydroxyapatite-covered pegs. Mucin, which promotes binding of hydroxyapatite and S. mutans (Kishimoto, Hay, & Gibbons, 1989), was present in all of the wells.
Previously it was reported that nHA-coated surfaces did not inhibit the growth of oral Streptococcus spp. during 24 h incubation (Abdulkareem et al., 2015). We showed that nHA in a saliva analog culture medium (BMM) enhanced biofilm formation and survival of S. mutans and also increased the culture pH during sucrose metabolism.
Transmission electron microscopy analysis has shown that nHA has increased surface area because of nano-sized holes in the particles (Abdulkareem et al., 2015). Guo, McLean, Lux, He, & Shi (2015) showed that glucans concentrate protons on the cell surface of S. mutans that trigger tolerance to acid stress. It is possible that increased biofilm formation by S. mutans in BMM medium containing nHA with sucrose not only resulted from an increase in the production of GtfB and GtfC but also from a higher surface area for attachment of glucans to nHA and bacterial surfaces. This may have resulted in the upregulation of the acid tolerance response in microcolonies (Guo et al., 2015).
It has been shown (Li & Burne, 2001) by using gtfBC promoters fused to a chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) gene and measuring the expression of the gtfBC-cat fusion, that the transcription of gtfBC is influenced by carbohydrates and environmental pH. We found that nHA affected the pH of the cultures and also influenced gtf transcription. The transcription of gtf genes in S. mutans is governed by regulatory genes (Biswas & Biswas, 2006; Stipp et al., 2013; Senpuku et al., 2018). At this time, it is not clear whether this was related to the effect on pH. Although various factors may be involved in the increase in biofilm formation observed in our study, it appears that enhanced transcription of gtf genes resulted in the increased production of enzymes involved in biofilm formation. Whereas gtfB and gtfC are arranged in one operon, gtfD is not linked to the gtfBC locus (Li & Burne, 2001). It appears that the transcription of gtfD was stimulated by nHA in BHI more than in BMM.
nHA, in addition to binding glucosyltransferases, can bind to other proteins (Pepla et al., 2014). It is not known if nHA interacts with regulatory proteins in S. mutans. An increase in proliferation of periodontal ligament cells in the presence of nHA has been attributed to the effect of the autophosphorylation of a receptor and activation of signalregulated kinases (Kasaj et al., 2008). Stimulation of two-component bacterial signal transduction systems (sensor kinase and response regulator) resulting in gene expression also has been shown to affect gtf genes in S. mutans (Biswas & Biswas, 2006).
These in vitro experiments have provided the first data to elucidate the influence of selected factors on the interaction of nHA with S. mutans and biofilm formation without interference from other factors in the complex oral environment. In the oral cavity, there are many other factors, including the oral microflora, influencing the activities of individual species. Further research is needed to understand the in vivo effect of nHA on the bacteria involved in dental diseases.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The enhancement of biofilm formation by nHA in S. mutans cultures that was observed may be the result of increased transcription of gtf genes, causing increased production of glucosyltransferases that function in polysaccharide synthesis. This may lead to the generation of higher amounts of GtfB and GtfC bound to glucans, cell surfaces and nHA to constitute biofilms. The reasons for enhanced transcription of gtf genes, which may be related to gene regulation, merit investigation. Understanding the effects of nanomaterials on microorganisms that induce biofilm-related oral diseases is important for the appropriate use of these compounds.

metadata.abstractText: Objectives: The aim of this study was to examine the effect of nano-hydroxyapatite (nHA) on biofilm formation by Streptococcus mutans, which is actively involved in the initiation of dental caries. Design: The effects of nHA on growth and biofilm formation by S. mutans were investigated in two media: a saliva analog medium, basal medium mucin (BMM); and a nutrient-rich medium, brain heart infusion (BHI); in the presence and absence of sucrose. Results: Sucrose enhanced the growth of S. mutans in both media. In the presence of sucrose, nHA enhanced bacterial growth and biofilm formation more in BMM medium than in BHI. nHA also affected the transcription of glucosyltransferase (gtf) genes and production of polysaccharide differently in the two media. In BHI medium, the transcription of all three gtf genes, coding for enzymes that synthesize soluble and insoluble glucans from sucrose, was increased more than 3-fold by nHA. However, in BMM medium, only the transcription of gtfB and gtfC, coding for insoluble glucans, was substantially enhanced
